page.title: 18Tradition
page.content: Each year in Mid-December a ceremony is held in front of St. John's Church, Glastonbury. A short service is held as townsfolk, visitors, and children from St. John's Infant School gather with the Mayoral party round the{Holy Thorn tree.}It is a descendant of the Holy Thorn which legend tells sprang up when{Joseph of {Arimathea}planted his staff on Wearyall Hill. Legend tells how the Thorn has since bloomed twice annually, at Christmas, to commemorate the birth of Christ, and again in the Spring. Sprigs of the Holy Thorn are cut by the Vicar, Mayor and a child from the school. These sprigs are then sent with the good wishes of all the towns- folk to{Her Majesty the Queen,}and the {Queen Mother.}The sprigs adorn their breakfast trays on Christmas Day.
